awd_titl_txt: Genetic Control of Vulval and Uterine Coordination in C. elegans: egl-26 and vulF
awd_abstract_narration: Many if not most human organs have ducts or tubes that contribute to organ function. The molecular and genetic mechanisms that direct cells to form the walls of tubes surrounding open lumens are not fully elucidated. This project aims to address the question "How do cells form tubes?" There isn't just one answer to this question because the cellular rearrangements contributing to tube formation in different organs and even within different areas of a single biological tube are varied. However, it is important to understand multiple specific examples of tube formation because failure of these biological programs can result in birth defects (for example, lack of connection between two tubes such as the esophagus and the stomach), and excess activity of these programs can contribute to disease (for example, blood vessel formation promotes tumor growth). This project will focus on understanding tube formation in the reproductive system in the microscopic nematode C elegans. Genetic approaches will allow discovery of new genes affecting tubulogenesis. By using microscopy on live developing tissues, the specific changes in cell structure that accompany tube formation will also be determined. Many biological mechanisms first revealed in C. elegans have proven relevant to all metazoans. Thus, the project has broad intellectual merit because tubulogenesis principles elucidated in C. elegans will have corollaries in other systems and, thus, wide-reaching significance to our understanding of organ formation. A core part of this project is a formal course with an integrated research component that will serve to recruit and train undergraduate students to pursue advanced degrees in biology.  Similarly, graduate students will be trained in preparation for independent science careers.  Thus, the project has broad merit in the educational realm as well. An important outcome from the completed study will be the preparation of the next generation of scientists.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The Hanna-Rose laboratory aims to acquire knowledge of the molecular pathways that determine proper formation of organs during the process of embryonic development. They use the egg-laying apparatus in the microscopic nematode called Caenorhabditis elegans as a model. In particular, they study the formation of the vulva, which forms a biological tube through which eggs are laid. The vulval is a simple tube formed from only twenty-two cells. Yet, the formation of this organ is complex, involving a myriad of signals exchanged between cells, causing them to adopt various fates and undergo changes in position and shape, giving rise to the mature organ. The elucidation of the signal transduction pathways that are important in vulva formation has been a major focus in the field for years. However, the focus of this project in the Hanna-Rose lab was to begin to define more of the genes that are required for the changes in cell shape and position at the latter stages of morphogenesis of this tube. In particular they had previously uncovered a novel mechanism for making an opening, or lumen, in a sheet of epithelial cells, which resulted in the connection between the lumen of the vulva and that of the uterus. In this project they aimed to identify additional molecular players and cellular mechanisms that were contributing to lumen formation.

A large team of undergraduates working over the period of the grant screened over 250 candidate genes for a role in the process. They identified multiple genes that work with previously known genes in known pathways as well as genes that work in previously unknown ways.

For example, the gene egl-26 was previously known to be important for maintaining the shape of the lumen after its formation. Five of the genes identified in the screen act to regulate the temporal and spatial pattern of egl-26 expression. Thus, they have begun to elucidate the regulatory network of genes that control morphogenesis.

Genes identified that play new roles include aspm-1, which acts to control orientation of divisions of the vulval lineage, thereby influencing cell position in the mature vulva, and gei-4, which they have shown shares phenotypes with intermediate filament genes. GEI-4 and the IFA genes are important for  establishment of the dorsal vulval lumen and alignment of the vulva to the dorsal ventral axis.

A significant impact in the area of training and education was the development of a research-based Communities of Practice course that incorporated a team-based project based on the genetic screen described above. This approach allowed the lab to expand the number of undergraduate students trained each year from an average of five per year in the five years prior to the award to an average of 12 per year over the period of the award. These students also received an enhanced level of training as participants in the Communities of Practice course. Via REU funds, Dr. Hanna-Rose has also offered internship experiences to an undergraduate from her alma mater, Anderson University, a small teaching institute where students there have fewer opportunities to do any research.

As with other models for studying tubulogenesis, principles elucidated for the C. elegans vulva will likely have corollaries in other systems and, thus, wide-reaching significance to the field of organogenesis. Ultimately, the lab aims to apply knowledge of how organogenesis of the vulval-uterine connection in C. elegans is executed to understanding how defects in organogenesis during mammalian development can result in physical birth defects.


Last Modified: 03/08/2016
Modified by: Wendy Hanna-Rose
